theorems.eq: $\text{(a) p} \wedge (p \vee q)\ \equiv\ p\\\text{(b) p} \vee (p \wedge q)\ \equiv\ p$
theorems.name: Absorption

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) p} \wedge (\neg p \vee q)\ \equiv\ p \wedge q\\\text{(b) p} \vee (\neg p \wedge q)\ \equiv\ p \vee q$
theorems.name: Absorption

theorems.eq: $(p \wedge q) \vee (\neg p \wedge r) \vee (q \wedge r)\ \equiv\ (p \wedge q) \vee (\neg p \wedge r)$
theorems.name: Consensus

theorems.eq:
$	ext{(a) } 
eg (p \wedge q)\ \equiv\ 
eg p \vee 
eg q\	ext{(b) }
eg (p \vee q)\ \equiv\ 
eg p \wedge 
eg q$
theorems.name: De Morgan

theorems.eq: $p \wedge (q \equiv r)\ \equiv\ p \wedge q\ \equiv\ p \wedge r\ \equiv\ p$
$(p \wedge q) \wedge r\ \equiv\ p\ \equiv\ q\ \equiv\ r\ \equiv\ \\\>\>\>\>\>\>\>p \vee q\ \equiv\ q \vee r\ \equiv\ r \vee p\ \equiv\ p \vee q \vee r$

$\text{(a) p} \Rightarrow p \vee q\\\text{(b) p}\wedge q \Rightarrow p\\\text{(c) p} \wedge q \Rightarrow p \vee q\\\text{(d) p} \vee (q \wedge r) \Rightarrow p \vee q\\\text{(e) p} \wedge q \Rightarrow p \wedge (q \vee r)$
theorems.name: Weakening/strengthening

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) (p }\Rightarrow q) \wedge (q \Rightarrow r) \Rightarrow (p \Rightarrow r)\\\text{(b) (p} \equiv q) \wedge (q \Rightarrow r) \Rightarrow (p \Rightarrow r)\\\text{(c) (p} \Rightarrow q) \wedge (q \equiv r) \Rightarrow (p \Rightarrow r)$
theorems.name: Transitivity

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) (e = f)} \wedge E^z_e\ \equiv\ (e = f) \wedge E^z_f\\\text{(b) (e = f)} \Rightarrow E^z_e\ \equiv\ (e = f) \Rightarrow E^z_f\\\text{(c) q} \wedge (e = f) \Rightarrow E^z_e\ \equiv\ q \wedge (e = f) \Rightarrow E^z_f$
theorems.name: Substitution

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) p }\Rightarrow E^z_p\ \equiv\ p \Rightarrow E^z_\textit{true}\\\text{(b) q}\wedge p \Rightarrow E^z_p\ \equiv\ q \wedge p \Rightarrow E^z_\textit{true}$
theorems.name: Replace by $\textit{true}$

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) }E^z_p \Rightarrow p\ \equiv\ E^z_\textit{false} \Rightarrow p\\\text{(b) }E^z_p \Rightarrow p \vee q\ \equiv\ E^z_\textit{false} \Rightarrow p \vee q$
theorems.name: Replace by $\textit{false}$

theorems.eq: To prove $P_1 \wedge P_2 \Rightarrow Q$, assume $P_1$ and $P_2$, and prove $Q$.$\\$You cannot use textual subsitution in $P_1$ or $P_2$.
theorems.name: Deduction (assume conjuncts of antecedent)

theorems.eq: If $E^z_\textit{true}$ and $E^z_\textit{false}$ are theorems, then so is $E^z_p$.
theorems.name: Case analysis

theorems.eq: $(p \vee q \vee r) \wedge (p \Rightarrow s) \wedge (q \Rightarrow s) \wedge (r \Rightarrow s)\ \Rightarrow\ s$
theorems.name: Case analysis

theorems.eq: To prove $P \equiv Q$, prove $P \Rightarrow Q$ and $Q \Rightarrow P$.
theorems.name: Mutual implication

theorems.eq: To prove $P \Rightarrow Q$, prove $\neg Q \Rightarrow \neg P$.
theorems.name: Proof by contrapositive

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided } \textit{P, Q : }\mathbb{B} \text{ or }\textit{R }\text{is finite,}\\(\star x\mid R:P) \star (\star x \mid R: Q) = (\star x \mid R : P \star Q)$
theorems.name: Distributivity

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\textit{R }\wedge\textit{ S }\equiv\textit{ false }\text{and }\textit{P : }\mathbb{B}\text{ or }\textit{R }\text{and }\textit{S }\text{are finite,}\\(\star x\mid R \vee S : P) = (\star x \mid R: P) \star (\star x \mid S : P)$
theorems.name: Range split for independent R and S

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\textit{P : }\mathbb{B}\text{ or }\textit{R }\text{and }\textit{S}\text{ are finite,}\\(\star x\mid R \vee S : P) \star (\star x \mid R \wedge S : P) = (\star x \mid R : P) \star (\star x \mid S : P)$
theorems.name: Range split

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\star\text{ is idempotent or}\textit{ R }\text{and}\textit{ Q }\text{ are finite,}\\(\star x\mid R \vee S : P) = (\star x\mid R : P) \star (\star x\mid S : P)$
theorems.name: Range split for idempotent $\star$

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\star\text{ is idempotent or }\textit{R }\text{and }\textit{Q }\text{are finite,}\\\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'y', 'R'}\text{ ), }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'Q'}\text{ )}\\(\star x\mid R : (\star y\mid Q : P)) = (\star y\mid R : (\star x \mid Q : P))$
theorems.name: Interchange of dummies

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'y', 'R,'}\text{ ),}\\(\star x, y \mid R \wedge Q : P) = (\star x \wedge R : (\star y \mid Q : P))$
theorems.name: Nesting

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'y', 'R, P'}\text{ ),}\\(\star x \mid R : P) = (\star y \mid R[x := y] : P[x := y])$
theorems.name: Dummy renaming

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'y', 'R, P'}\text{ ), and }\textit{f }\text{ has an inverse,}\\(\star x \mid R : P) = (\star y \mid R[x := f.y]: P[x := f.y])$
theorems.name: Change of dummy

theorems.eq: $\text{For }\textit{n: }\mathbb{N,}\\\text{(a) }(\star i \mid 0 \le i < n + 1 : P) = (\star i \mid 0 \le i < n : P) \star P[i := n]\\\text{(b) }(\star i \mid 0 \le i < n + 1 : P) = P[i := 0] \star (\star i \mid 0 < i < n + 1: P)$
theorems.name: Split off term

theorems.subtext: Notation: $\star x \mid : P)$ means $(\star x \mid \textit{true} : P)$.
theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid : R \Rightarrow P)$
theorems.name: Trading

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) }(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid : \neg R \vee P)\\\text{(b) }(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid : R \wedge P \equiv R)\\\text{(c) }(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid : R \vee P \equiv P)$
theorems.name: Trading

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) }(\forall x \mid Q \wedge R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid Q : R \Rightarrow P)\\\text{(b) }(\forall x \mid Q \wedge R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid Q : \neg R \vee P)\\\text{(c) }(\forall x \mid Q \wedge R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid Q : R \wedge P \equiv R)\\\text{(d) }(\forall x \mid Q \wedge R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid Q : R \vee P \equiv P)$
theorems.name: Trading

theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid \neg P: \neg R)$
theorems.name: Universal double trading

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'P'}\text{ ),}\\P \vee (\forall x \mid R : Q) \equiv (\forall x \mid R : P \vee Q)$
theorems.name: Distributivity of $\vee$ over $\forall$

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'P'}\text{ ),}\\(\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv P \vee (\forall x \mid : \neg R)$
$\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'P'}\text{ ),}\\\neg (\forall x \mid : \neg R) \Rightarrow ((\forall x \mid R: P \wedge Q) \equiv P \wedge (\forall x \mid R : Q))$
theorems.name: Distributivity of $\wedge$ over $\forall$

theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : P \equiv Q) \Rightarrow ((\forall x \mid R : P) \equiv (\forall x \mid R : Q))$
$(\forall x \mid Q \vee R : P) \Rightarrow (\forall x \mid Q : P)$
theorems.name: Range weakening/strengthening

theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : P \wedge Q) \Rightarrow (\forall x \mid R: P)$
theorems.name: Body weakening/strengthening

theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : Q \Rightarrow P) \Rightarrow ((\forall x \mid R : Q) \Rightarrow (\forall x \mid R : P))$
theorems.name: Monotonicity of $\forall$

theorems.eq: $P \text{ is a theorem iff }(\forall x \mid : P) \text{ is a theorem.}$
theorems.name: Metatheorem

theorems.eq:
$	ext{(a) }
eg (\exists x \mid R : 
eg P) \equiv ( orall x \mid R : P)\	ext{(b) }
eg (\exists x \mid R : P) \equiv ( orall x \mid R: 
eg P)\	ext{(c) }(\exists x \mid R : 
eg P) \equiv 
eg ( orall x \mid R : P)$
theorems.name: Generalized De Morgan

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid R : P) \equiv (\exists x \mid : R \wedge P)$
theorems.name: Trading

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid Q \wedge R : P) \equiv (\exists x \mid Q : R \wedge P)$
theorems.name: Trading

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid R : P) \equiv (\exists x \mid P : R)$
theorems.name: Existential double trading

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid : R) \Rightarrow ((\forall x \mid R : P) \Rightarrow (\exists x \mid R : P))$
$\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'P' }\text{),}\\P \wedge (\exists x \mid R : Q) \equiv (\exists x \mid R : P \wedge Q)$
theorems.name: Distributivity of $\wedge$ over $\exists$

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'P' }\text{),}\\(\exists x \mid R : P) \equiv P \wedge (\exists x \mid : R)$
$(\exists x \mid : R) \Rightarrow ((\exists x \mid R : P \vee Q) \equiv P \vee (\exists x \mid R : Q)$
theorems.name: Distributivity of $\vee$ over $\exists$

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid R : P) \Rightarrow (\exists x \mid Q \vee R : P)$
theorems.name: Range weakening/strengthening

theorems.eq: $(\exists x \mid R : P) \Rightarrow (\exists x \mid R : P \vee Q)$
theorems.name: Body weakening/strengthening

theorems.eq: $(\forall x \mid R : Q \Rightarrow P) \Rightarrow ((\exists x \mid R : Q) \Rightarrow (\exists x \mid R : P))$
theorems.name: Monotonicity of $\exists$

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'y', 'R' }\text{)}\text{ and }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{(}\textit{'x', 'Q' }\text{),}\\(\exists x \mid R : (\forall y \mid Q : P)) \Rightarrow (\forall y \mid Q : (\exists x \mid R : P))$
theorems.name: Interchange of quantification

theorems.eq: $\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{('}\hat{x}\textit{', 'Q' }\text{),}\\(\exists x \mid R : P) \Rightarrow Q \text{ is a theorem iff (R} \wedge P)[x := \hat{x}] \Rightarrow Q \text{ is a theorem.}$
$\{e_0, \dots , e_{n - 1}\} = \{x \mid x = e_0 \vee \dots \vee x = e_{n - 1} : x\}$
$\text{Provided }\neg\textit{occurs}\text{('}\textit{x', 'F'}\text{ ),}\\F \in \{x \mid R : E\} \equiv (\exists x \mid R : F = E)$
theorems.name: Set membership

theorems.eq: $S = T\ \ \equiv\ \ (\forall x \mid : x \in S\ \equiv\ x \in T)$
theorems.name: Extensionallity

theorems.eq: $\{x \mid R : E\} = \{y \mid (\exists x \mid R: y = E)\}$
$x \in \{x \mid R\}\ \equiv\ R\\\textit{R }\text{is the characteristic predicate of the set.}$
$\{x \mid Q\} = \{x \mid R\} \text{ is valid iff } Q \equiv R \text{ is valid.}$

$\text{(a) Use Leibniz directly.}\\\text{(b) Use axiom Extensionality (11.4) and prove}\\\text{the (9.8) Lemma }v \in S\ \equiv\ v \in T\text{ for an arbitrary value }\textit{v}.\\\text{(c) Prove }\textit{Q }\equiv\textit{ R }\text{and conclude }\{x \mid Q\} = \{x \mid R\}.$
theorems.name: Methods for proving set equality $\textit{S }= \textit{T}:$

theorems.eq: $S \subseteq T\ \equiv\ (\forall x \mid x \in S : x \in T)$
theorems.name: Subset

theorems.eq: $v \in S \cup T\ \equiv\ v \in S \vee v \in T$
theorems.name: Union

theorems.eq: $v \in S \cap T\ \equiv\ v \in S \wedge v \in T$
theorems.name: Intersection

theorems.eq: $v \in S - T\ \equiv\ v \in S \wedge v \not \in T$
theorems.name: Difference

theorems.eq: $\text{Let }E_s\text{ be a set expression constructed from set variables, }\emptyset, \textbf{U}, \sim, \cup,\text{ and }\cap.\\\text{Then }E_p\text{ is the expression constructed from }E_s\text{ by replacing: }\\ \ \ \text{(a) }\emptyset\text{ with }\textit{false},\\ \ \ \text{(b) }\textbf{U}\text{ with }\textit{true},\\ \ \ \text{(c) }\cup\text{ with }\vee,\\ \ \ \text{(d) }\cap\text{ with }\wedge,\\ \ \ \text{(e) }\sim\text{ with }\neg.\\\text{The construction is reversible: }E_s\text{ can be constructed from }E_p.$
theorems.name: Definition. $E_p$

theorems.eq: $\text{For any set expressions }E_s\text{ and }F_s\\ \ \ \text{(a) }E_s = F_s\text{ is valid iff }E_p \equiv F_p\text{ is valid,}\\ \ \ \text{(b) }E_s \subseteq F_s\text{ is valid iff }E_p \rightarrow F_p\text{ is valid,}\\ \ \ \text{(c) }E_s = \textbf{U}\text{ is valid iff }E_p\text{ is valid.}$
theorems.name: Metatheorem

theorems.eq: $\text{(a) }\sim (S \cup T)\ =\ \sim S\;\cap \sim T\\\text{(b) }\sim (S \cap T)\ =\ \sim S\;\cup \sim T$
theorems.name: De Morgan

theorems.eq: $S \cup T = \mathbf{U}\ \equiv\ (\forall x \mid x \in \textbf{U} : x \not \in S \Rightarrow x \in T)$
$S \cap T = \emptyset\ \equiv\ (\forall x \mid : x \in S \Rightarrow x \not \in T)$
$S \subset T\ \equiv\ S \subseteq T \wedge (\exists x \mid x \in T : x \not \in S)$
$(\exists x \mid x \in S: x \not \in T)\ \Rightarrow\ S \neq T$

$\text{(a) }S \subseteq T \wedge T \subset U\ \Rightarrow\ S \subset U\\\text{(b) }S \subset T \wedge T \subseteq U\ \Rightarrow\ S \subset U\\\text{(c) }S \subset T \wedge T \subset U\ \Rightarrow\ S \subset U$
theorems.name: Transitivity

theorems.eq: $\text{Set }S\text{ partitions }T\text{ if}\\\text{(i) the sets in }S\text{ are pairwise disjoint and}\\\text{(ii) the union of the sets in }S\text{ is }T\text{, that is, if}\\(\forall u,v\mid u \in S \wedge v \in S \wedge u \neq v: u \cap v = \emptyset) \wedge (\cup u \mid u \in S : u) = T$
theorems.name: Partition

theorems.eq: $v \in \lbag x \mid R : E \rbag\ \equiv\ (\exists x \mid R : v = E) $
theorems.name: Membership

theorems.eq: $(\forall n : \mathbb{N} \mid : (\forall i \mid 0 \leq i < n : P.i) \Rightarrow P.n)\ \Rightarrow\ (\forall n : \mathbb{N} \mid : P.n)$
theorems.name: Mathematical induction over $\mathbb{N}$

theorems.eq: $(\forall n: \mathbb{N} \mid : (\forall i \mid 0 \leq i < n: P.i) \Rightarrow P.n)\ \equiv\ (\forall n: \mathbb{N} \mid : P.n)$
theorems.name: Mathematical induction over $\mathbb{N}$

theorems.eq: $P.0 \wedge (\forall n:\mathbb{N} \mid : (\forall i \mid 0 \leq i \leq n : P.i) \Rightarrow P.(n + 1))\\\ \ \ \ \equiv\ (\forall n : \mathbb{N} \mid : P.n)$
theorems.name: Mathematical induction over $\mathbb{N}$

theorems.eq: $F_{n + m} = F_{m} \cdot F_{n + 1} + F_{m - 1} \cdot F_{n}\quad\text{for }n \geq 0\text{ and }m \geq 1$
$\emptyset\text{ is a binary tree, called the empty tree.}\\\#(d,l,r)\text{ is a binary tree, for } d: \mathbb{Z}\text{ and } l, r\text{ binary trees.}$
theorems.name: Definition, Binary Tree

theorems.eq: $\text{A leaf is a node with no children (i.e. two empty subtrees).}$
theorems.name: Definition, Leaf

theorems.eq: $\text{An internal node is a node that is not a leaf.}$
theorems.name: Definition, Internal Node

theorems.eq: $\text{A binary tree is complete if every node has}\\\text{either 0 or 2 children.}$
theorems.name: Definition, Complete

theorems.eq: $\text{The maximum number of nodes in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }2^{n}-1\quad\text{for }n \geq 0\text{.}$
$\text{The minimum number of nodes in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }n\quad\text{for }n \geq 0\text{.}$

$\text{(a) The maximum number of leaves in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }2^{n - 1}\quad\text{for }n > 0\text{.}\\\text{(b) The maximum number of internal nodes in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }2^{n - 1} - 1\quad\text{for }n > 0\text{.}$

$\text{(a) The minimum number of leaves in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }1\quad\text{for }n > 0\text{.}\\\text{(b) The minimum number of internal nodes in a tree with}\\\text{height }n\text{ is }n - 1\quad\text{for }n > 0\text{.}$
$\text{Every nonempty complete tree has an odd number of nodes.}$
$\text{To show that }x := E\text{ is an implementation of }\{Q\}\;S\;\{R\}\text{,}\\\text{prove }Q \Rightarrow R[x := E]\text{.}$
theorems.name: Proof method for assignment

theorems.eq: $\mathbf{if}\ B1 \rightarrow S1\\\square\ B2 \rightarrow S2\\\square\ B3 \rightarrow S3\\\mathbf{fi}$
theorems.name: $IFG$

theorems.eq: $\text{To prove }\{Q\}\;IFG\;\{R\}\text{, it suffices to prove}\\\text{(a) }Q \Rightarrow B1 \vee B2 \vee B3\text{,}\\\text{(b) }\{Q \wedge B1\}\;S1\;\{R\}\text{,}\\\text{(c) }\{Q \wedge B2\}\;S2\;\{R\}\text{, and}\\\text{(d) }\{Q \wedge B3\}\;S3\;\{R\}\text{.}$
theorems.name: Proof method for $IFG$

theorems.eq: $\quad\mathbf{if}\ B1 \rightarrow S1\;;T\;\square\;B2 \rightarrow S2\;;T\ \mathbf{fi}\\=\\\quad\mathbf{if}\ B1 \rightarrow S1\;\square\;B2 \rightarrow S2\ \mathbf{fi}\;;\;T$
theorems.name: Distributivity of program over alternation

theorems.eq:
$\text{Suppose}$
  • $\{P \wedge B\}\;S\;\{P\}\ \text{holds --- i.e. execution of S begun in a state}\\\text{in which }P\text{ and }B\text{ are }\textit{true}\text{ terminates with }P\textit{ true}\text{ --- and}$
  • $\{P\}\ \mathbf{do}\ B \rightarrow S\ \mathbf{od}\ \{\textit{true}\}\text{ --- i.e. execution of the loop begun}\\\text{in a state in which }P\text{ is }\textit{true}\text{ terminates.}$

    • $\text{Then }\{P\}\ \mathbf{do}\ B \rightarrow S\ \mathbf{od}\ \{P \wedge \neg B\}\ \text{holds.}$
theorems.name: Fundamental Invariance Theorem

theorems.eq: $\text{To prove }\{Q\}\;\textit{initialization}\text{;}\;\{P\}\ \mathbf{do}\ B \rightarrow S\ \mathbf{od}\ \{R\}\text{,}\\\text{it suffices to prove}\\\text{(a) }P \text{ is }\textit{true}\text{ before execution of the loop: }\{Q\}\;\textit{initialization}\text{;}\;{P}\text{,}\\\text{(b) }P\text{ is a loop invariant: }\{P \wedge B\}\;S\;\{P\}\text{,}\\\text{(c) Execution of the loop terminates, and}\\\text{(d) }R\text{ holds upon termination: }P \wedge \neg B \Rightarrow R\text{.}$
theorems.name: Proof method for $DO$

theorems.eq: $\langle b,c \rangle = \langle b', c'\rangle\ \equiv\ \ b = b' \wedge c = c'$
theorems.name: Pair equality
